title: 108_s822
content: The "Child Care Lending Pilot Act of 2003" may be cited as the short title. It establishes the Child Care Business Loan Program. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to authorize loans with restrictions and limitations. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to authorize loans with restrictions and limitations, including the use of proceeds for small, non-profit child care businesses. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow loans for small, non-profit child care businesses, subject to specific conditions and reporting requirements. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow loans for small, non-profit child care businesses, with reporting requirements to the Small Business Administration every 6 months. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include loans for small, non-profit child care businesses. Reporting requirements to the Small Business Administration every 6 months include details on program implementation, rules issuance, and loan statistics. The General Accounting Office must submit a report by March 31, 2006. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report on child care small business loans to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business by March 31, 2006, detailing the number and dollar amount of loans approved and disbursed in the previous 6 months. The report on child care small business loans must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business by March 31, 2006. It will include information gathered during the first 2 years of the loan program, evaluating implementation timeliness, participation effectiveness, marketing strategies, and more. The report on child care small business loans, due by March 31, 2006, will assess participation effectiveness, marketing strategies, and the number of businesses applying, approved, and receiving loans under the program. The report will assess businesses that applied for, were approved, and received loans under the program, including details on the number of businesses in each state, total amount loaned, and average loan amount and term. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will issue final rules within 120 days of the enactment of the Act to implement the loan program. The amendments made by this section will be in effect until September 30, 2006, applying to all loans authorized during the specified period.
